problem_text:
We say that two subsets A, B of an infinite group G are separated if there exists an infinite subset X of G such that 1 ∈ X, X = X−1, and XAX ∩ B = ∅. Is it true that any two disjoint subsets A, B of an infinite group G satisfying |A| < |G|, |B| < |G| are separated? This is so if A, B are finite, or G is Abelian.
I. V. Protasov
